## Exercise 1
A researcher has collected $n = 15$ observations that are supposed to come from a Normal distribution with known variance $\sigma^2 = 16$:

`26.8, 26.3, 28.3, 28.5, 16.3, 31.9, 28.5, 27.2, 20.9, 27.5, 28.0, 18.6, 22.3, 25.0, 31.5`

Assuming a normal prior for $\mu$, $\mathcal{N}(m=20, s^2=25)$:

a. Determine the posterior distribution $P(\mu | y_1,\dots,y_{15})$ and find the posterior mean and standard deviation.

```{r}
library(latex2exp)

s.known <- 4
N <- 15
data <- c(26.8, 26.3, 28.3, 28.5, 16.3, 31.9, 28.5, 27.2, 20.9, 27.5, 28.0, 18.6, 22.3, 25.0, 31.5)
m.data <- mean(data)
cat("Mean of the data = ", m.data, "\n")
s.prior <- 5
m.prior <- 20
s.post <- s.known*s.prior/(sqrt(s.known^2+N*s.prior^2))
#m.post <- (1/s.prior^2)*m.prior/(1/s.known^2 + 1/s.prior^2) + (N/s.known^2)*m.data/(N/s.known^2 + 1/s.prior^2)
#s.post <- sqrt((1/s.prior))
m.post <- (s.post^2)*(m.prior/s.prior^2 + m.data*N/s.known^2)

x <- seq(1, 60, 0.1)
post <- dnorm(x, m.post, s.post)

cat("Posterior mean =", m.post, "\n")
cat("Posterior standard deviation =", s.post)
```

b. Find the 95% credibility interval for $\mu$.

```{r}
x1 <- x[which.min(abs(0.025-cumsum(post)*0.1))]
x2 <- x[which.min(abs(0.975-cumsum(post)*0.1))]
cat("The 95% credibility interval is given by [x1, x2] = [", x1, ",", x2, "]")
```

c. Plot the posterior distribution, indicating on the same plot: the mean value, the standard deviation, and the 95% credibility interval.

```{r}
plot(x, post,
     type = "l",
     xlim = c(20, 30),
     col = "royalblue",
     xlab = TeX("$\\mu$"),
     ylab = TeX("P($\\mu$ | y_1,...,y_{15})"),
     main = "Posterior distribution")

text(39, 0.38, paste("mean =", round(m.post,0)))
text(39, 0.34, paste("std =", round(s.post,1)))
abline(v = m.post, lty = 2, col = "royalblue3")
x.between = x[x>x1 & x<x2]
dens.between = post[x>x1 & x<x2]
polygon(c(x.between, rev(x.between)), c(rep(0, length(x.between)), rev(dens.between)), col="royalblue", density=10)
legend("topright", legend = c("Posterior", "Mean", "95% C.I."), fill = c("royalblue", "royalblue3", "royalblue"))
```

d. repeat the analysis using a different prior $\mathcal{N}(m=30, s^2=16)$ and plot, on the same graph the likelihood, the prior and the posterior.

```{r}
s.prior <- 4
m.prior <- 30

prior.new <- dnorm(x, m.prior, s.prior)

likelihood <- Vectorize(function(mu, s) {
  l <- 1/(sqrt(2*pi)*s)*exp(-(sum(data-mu)^2)/(2*s^2))
  return(l)
})

s.post <- s.known*s.prior/(sqrt(s.known^2+N*s.prior^2))
#m.post <- (1/s.prior^2)*m.prior/(1/s.known^2 + 1/s.prior^2) + (N/s.known^2)*m.data/(N/s.known^2 + 1/s.prior^2)
m.post <- (s.post^2)*(m.prior/s.prior^2 + m.data*N/s.known^2)

likelihood.norm <- likelihood(x, s.known)/(sum(likelihood(x, s.known))*0.1)

post.new <- dnorm(x, m.post, s.post)/sum(dnorm(x, m.post, s.post)*0.1)

#post.new1 <- prior.new*likelihood(x, s.known)/(sum(prior.new*likelihood(x, s.known))*0.1)

plot(x, likelihood.norm,
     type = "l",
     col = "royalblue",
     xlab = TeX("$\\mu$"),
     ylab = "Posterior",
     main = "Posterior distribution")

lines(x, prior.new,
      type = "l",
      col = "coral2")

lines(x, post.new,
      type = "l",
      col = "springgreen3")

legend("topright", c("Likelihood", "Prior", "Posterior"), col = c("royalblue", "coral2", "springgreen3"), lwd = 3)
```

e. Compare the credibility intervals obtained with the two priors.

```{r}
x1.new <- x[which.min(abs(0.025-cumsum(post.new)*0.1))]
x2.new <- x[which.min(abs(0.975-cumsum(post.new)*0.1))]
cat("The 95% credibility interval is given by [x1, x2] = [", x1.new, ",", x2.new, "]")
```


## Exercise 2
A researcher has collected $n = 16$ observations that are supposed to come from a Normal distribution with known variance $\sigma^2 = 4$:

`4.09, 4.68, 1.87, 2.62, 5.58, 8.68, 4.07, 4.78, 4.79, 4.49, 5.85, 5.09, 2.40, 6.27, 6.30, 4.47`

Assuming the prior is a step function:

$$
g(\mu) = 
\begin{cases}
  \mu   & \text{for } 0<\mu\le 3 \\
  3     & \text{for } 3<\mu\le 5 \\
  8-\mu & \text{for } 5<\mu\le 8 \\
  0     & \text{for } \mu > 8
\end{cases}
$$

a. Find the posterior distribution, the posterior mean and standard deviation.

```{r}
n <- 16
s.known <- 2
data <- c(4.09, 4.68, 1.87, 2.62, 5.58, 8.68, 4.07, 4.78, 4.79, 4.49, 5.85, 5.09, 2.40, 6.27, 6.30, 4.47)

prior <- function(mu) {
  val <- ifelse(0 < mu & mu <= 3, mu,
                ifelse(3 < mu & mu <= 5, 3,
                       ifelse(5 < mu & mu <= 8, 8 - mu, 0)))
  return(val)
}

mu <- seq(0,10,0.01)

#like <- dnorm(mu, mean = mean(data), sd = s.known)/sum(dnorm(mu, mean = mean(data), sd = s.known)*0.01)

likelihood <- Vectorize(function(mu, s) {
  l <- 1/(sqrt(2*pi)*s)*exp(-(sum(data-mu)^2)/(2*s^2))
  return(l)
})

likelihood.norm <- likelihood(mu, s.known)/(sum(likelihood(mu, s.known))*0.01)
post.star <- likelihood.norm*prior(mu)
post.norm <- post.star/(sum(post.star)*0.01)

mu.max <- mu[which.max(post.norm)]

cat("The maximum of the posterior is:", mu.max)
```

b. Find the 95% credibility interval for $\mu$.

```{r}
mu1 <- mu[which.min(abs(0.025-cumsum(post.norm)*0.01))]
mu2 <- mu[which.min(abs(0.975-cumsum(post.norm)*0.01))]
cat("The 95% credibility interval is given by [x1, x2] = [", mu1, ",", mu2, "]")
```

c. Plot the posterior distribution, indicating on the same plot: the mean value, the standard deviation, and the 95% credibility interval.

```{r}
options(repr.plot.width=12, repr.plot.height=10)
# Code for polygon function
mu.p <- seq(mu1, mu2, 0.01)

x <- c(mu1, mu.p, mu2)

likelihood.norm.95 <- likelihood(mu.p, s.known)/(sum(likelihood(mu.p, s.known))*0.01)
post.star.95 <- likelihood.norm.95*prior(mu.p)
post.norm.95 <- post.star.95/(sum(post.star.95)*0.01)

y <- c(0, post.norm.95, 0)

plot(mu, post.norm, 
     xaxs='i', yaxs='i', col='navy', 
     type='l', lty=1, lwd=3, 
     xlab="p",
     xlim = c(4,6),
     ylim = c(0,5),
     ylab=expression(paste("P","(p | y,n,M)")),
     main='Posterior',
     pch=2)

polygon(x=x, y=y, col='seagreen1', pch=1)
abline(v=mu.max,    col="grey40", lty=2, pch=1)
abline(v=mu1, col="grey40", lty=2, pch=1)
abline(v=mu2, col="grey40", lty=2, pch=1)
text(mu.max, 4, labels = expression("x"["m"]),     pos = 1, cex = 2, col="red", xpd=TRUE)
text(mu1, 4, labels = expression("x"["2.5%"]),  pos = 1, cex = 2, col="red", xpd=TRUE)
text(mu2, 4, labels = expression("x"["97.5%"]), pos = 1, cex = 2, col="red", xpd=TRUE)
```

d. Plot, on the same graph, the prior, the likelihood and the posterior distribution.

```{r}
plot(mu, post.norm,
     type = "l",
     lty = 2,
     col = "blue",
     xlab = TeX("$\\mu$"),
     ylab = "P",
     main = "Posterior, prior and likelihood distributions")
lines(mu, prior(mu)/15, # normalization
      type = "l",
      col = "red")
lines(mu, likelihood.norm,
      type = "l",
      lty = 1,
      col = "darkolivegreen4")
legend("topright", 
       c("Posterior", "Prior", "Likelihood"), 
       lwd = 3, 
       col = c("blue", "red", "darkolivegreen4"))
```


## Exercise 3
In a study on water quality of streams, a high level of bacter X was defined as a level greater than 100 per 100 ml of stream water. $n = 116$ samples were taken from streams having a high environmental impact on pandas. Out of these, $y = 11$ had a high bacter X level.

Indicating with $p$ the probability that a sample of water taken from the stream has a high bacter X level:

a. Find the frequentist estimator for $p$.

```{r}
n <- 116
y <- 11
p.freq <- 11/116
cat("The frequenty estimator is p =", p.freq)
```

b. Using a Beta$(1,10)$ prior for $p$, calculate and plot posterior distribution $P(p|y)$.

```{r}
alpha <- 1
beta <- 10
n.sample <- 2000
delta <- 1/n.sample
p <- seq(from=1/(2*n.sample), by=1/n.sample, length.out=n.sample)

prior <- dbeta(p, alpha, beta)

likelihood <- dbinom(y, n, p)

post.star <- dbeta(p, alpha + y, beta + n - y)
post.norm <- post.star/(sum(post.star)*delta) 

plot(p, post.norm, 
     type = "l",
     col = "red",
     ylab = "P(p|y)",
     xlab = "p",
     main = "Posterior")
```

c. Find the bayesian estimator for $p$, the posterior mean and variance, and a 95% credible interval.

```{r}
post.mean <- (alpha + y)/(alpha + beta + n)
#post.m <- sum(p*post.norm)/n.sample
post.var <- (1/(n+2)^2)*n*post.mean*(1-post.mean)
cat("The bayesian estimator is the posterior mean:", post.mean, "\n")
cat("The variance is:", post.var)
```
